name: The Ricky Gervais Guide to: The Future

transcript.content: To quote the scholar and political theorist John Shah, the future is not a result of choices among alternative paths offered by the present, but a place that is created. Created first in the mind and will, created next in activity. The future is not some place we are going to, but one we are creating. From the schoolboy dreaming of big adventures to the scientists envisioning groundbreaking discoveries, we all care to imagine what the future will bring. Many people have attempted to predict the future, others to mold and control it. But what do we really know of the future? How does the past inform it? And what educated guesses can we make about the shape of things to come? To discuss these questions and more, I'm joined by Stephen Merchant, award winning writer and graduate of the University of Warwick.
Hello.
And Karl Pilkington. Fucking mong.
Steve and Ricky laugh quietly
All right.

One prediction for the future, Steve, is from an academic study. What the world would be like in about 75 years from now. And a big prediction they're sort of sure of, is that androgyny will rule. There'd be so little difference between men and women apart from the biology. Economically, socially- It won't matter who the biggest bread winner is, that's already being phased out. If you're in a traditional heterosexual male-female couple, it won't be: who stays home, who earns the most or whatever. It won't be governed by gender, and that's getting less and less anyway as it is now. But soon you won't even need a female or a man in your life. You'll just need the egg or sperm and you'll be able to have any coupling you want or not. Thoughts, Steve?
That isn't what I've heard.
What were you heard?
So you read an academic study, Rick. But let's find out what Karl's been reading.
I heard we're... you know.. We're all going to go ugly.
Ricky sniggers
Different point though, innit? That is a different point
That's a completely different point there, not listening to a word Ricky said, but go on.
No, it's just if we all sort of go ugly, that will sort the population problem out.
He gets an extra syllable in the word "ugly". Uge-leh. Uge-leh. Uge-leh.
So that's just sorts the population out because people aren't sort of havin' it away. Left right and center.
What do you mean?
Sorry, Rick, I don't understand what the hell he said there.
Are you saying because everyone's ugly, everyone won't want to have it away more with the ugly person?
Yeah.
Okay, you seem to understand what he's talking about, Rick. I'm still confused.
What he thinks is that if we're all ugly, then we still have this strange paradigm of beauty that won't exist. So we won't fancy anyone as much?
No, they'll still sort of fancy- because at the end of the day, we're animals, aren't we?
Yeah
We'll still have it away, but not as much as they like to do now, because it's all based on looks.
Sorry, but what's this got to do with what Ricky said?
What's this world like? Describe a typical town or country.
It's exactly. Right, Imagine London. You've still got the Gherkin. You've still got the big wheel.
Right
That it's just everyone's ugly.
Right, and they're, and they're doing all the same jobs are they? They just
Everyone's still. Yeah. The worlds got to carry on
So, what do. What do they look like? What's ugly?
Just imagine, like, haven't you ever seen anyone when you've just gone, pfft, look at that.
Yeah.
Right, well like, like that.

Yeah, but hold on. It's ugly by today's standards, is it? So I throw forward to 75 years, you'll go, oh, everyone's what we call ugly. But what's happened to society? What do they think of everyone? They won't suddenly go "oh, aint it annoying, we've got, we've got uglier" because it's not because strict.

No because we have got better looking, haven't we? If I look back now, at a school photo, you look at my class and you go, what, what was going on then? You can't tell the difference between some of the girls and the blokes.
Steve laughs
No, but that's not true, because
It is honestly, you look at it and you see stuff.
That's fashion and nutrition, and I see that, yeah.
Yeah

When I see an old episode of Bullseye, I think, Jesus, the men look like rakes with no teeth and a moustache and they're bald with their hair down like a paedophile. And he goes, "and how old are you?" and I go "52, 50" he goes, "I'm 22." What?
Yeah, but that's more because of the sort of people that used to go on Bullseye. I mean, you know, Paul, Paul Newman was never going to pop on bullseye.
Ricky Laughs
Exactly. I know, exactly
You know, because he was actually a plumber from Essex.

And then think of the people that he grew up with, where he. I mean, some of them live in holes now. So, you know, I don't think your, the class of erm, Pilkey 1982 doesn't really count. When he said we've got better looking, I thought he was going to talk about cavemen, not his school photo. I mean, what happened there? There's been no evolution in that time. What are you talking about Karl?
We've got better looking now, haven't we?

I wonder if he's confused it with the paradigms of, of beauty have changed, haven't they? So in the 50s, Marilyn Monroe was, was considered you know, very desirable, whereas that body shape on women, more recently, has become, has become less. Lot's of skinny women are seen as a paradigm of beauty. But, so that has maybe changed.
But we will change, probably not in 75 years.

Yeah, we'll change just little things. I mentioned before about your little finger. There'll come a time, when that will go, I've said, I've watched it. I've kept an eye on what my little finger is doing.
Ricky and Steve laugh

Sometimes it does nothing. It never helps out. All the others are grabbing hold of stuff. That one just sort of sits there watching. So you could get rid of that. And I think that, that will go in evolution.
Think of the books he could have read when he was doing that, when he was monitoring his little finger.
Ricky continues to snigger

"I've been watching my little finger." But again, it's what you mean. 75 years is nothing. The only thing that changes in 75 years is, trend, fashion, economics. The gene pool doesn't change unless there's been some sort of really weird mutation due to an external force. That I, I don't know. For things of science fiction, where we all accidentally drank plutonium. We got three eyes and one leg. It doesn't happen that fast. I've told you before, if you shaved a caveman, he's basically us, he's basically us.
Well he's basically Karl
Ricky laughs
Yeah. Yeah, but erm. You know, the little finger, will be, let me tell you, millions of years
Uhmmm...

I think what's more interesting about the future, Karl, is the fact that technology integrated with humans will be fascinating. So, for instance, they're talking - you know - about the fact that in the future, we may even be able to have chips in our head that allow us to access the Internet, or an equivalent of it, directly, mentally - so imagine that...
Not-not-not, just gonna say, not french fries... he doesn't mean that
But hang on though... At what point are we us, then?
Here ya are, this is good...
Go on - Go on...
No, because, if I - if I - can go on the Internet at any time, then that's going to know more than me.
What does that mean?
Okay...
When I don't know an answer to something now...
Hmmm
..which is a lot of stuff.
Really?
Go on...
You watch University Challenge...
Yeah

...and the stuff them kids on that know... I just think, where have they stored that? Where's that gone in their head? How have they left that somewhere and it's just sat there waiting to be used? For me, if something doesn't get used within a time period, that's it...
But again -
...It's forgotten about.
But again. Okay. That's application and-and-and training and all that.
I don't think - I think tha-
But basically, you're - you've got about the same hardware as those people
I haven't. Honest to God, I haven't. I know I haven't.
Your brain capacity i-i-is huge...
It's not the same as theirs!
It's not the same.

Well, you might not be what's considered as academically intelligent as them, but again, an awful lot of it is - you know - nurture more than nature. Uhm, your brain is good. Your brain is up there. Don't worry about that.
Well, it isn't, but listen...
Steve laughs
...so what I'm saying is, if I want to know the answer to something, I go on the Internet.
Yeah.
Right.
Now, if I've got a chip in my head with Google on it -
Yuhp.
Ricky laughs
- I'm never going to use my head. I'll just be forever on Google.
Ricky bursts out laughing
(Repeating Karl) I'm never going to use my 'ed!
Well I'm not! Because what's the point -
But what do you think your head is though??
- Because I'm going to get it wrong. The chances are I'll get it wrong. So divert that. It's like saying...

No no... you can't bypass the brain straight to Google when - so you're having a chat socially - It's not like they're going, 'All right, Karl, how are you?' And you're not there. You're asleep and Google's talking. (Robotic Voice) 'I think you'll find that they're -'
(Rough accent) Do you want to see naked ladies? Come this way...
Ricky laughs
No, only for questions, though, that I don't know. But what I'm saying is, because I don't know a lot of the answers, I'll just say, forget it leave it connected to Google.
(Laughing) So.. no - no -
So then I'm not me anymore.
Well, what are you doing? Where's you gone?
I'm looking at Google.
Steve bursts out laughing
So it is you?
No! But what Steve just said is, we'll have a chip in our 'ed -
Hmmh.
Right.
- That can access the Internet.
Steve & Ricky mumble in agreement
So why-why bother using your own knowledge? -
You're still the go between. Your - You, Karl, are the go between the Internet and whatever your mouth says...
But you can't beat the internet!
Yes, but -
You can't - it knows everything...
You're accessing the information like it was part of your brain capacity, but you're still processing and using that information.
But - but hold on, where does Google get the information from in the first place?
Someone...one of them bright people on University Challenge -
... A human being.
Yeah.
Yeah. A human being.
But I'm going to get lazier. I don't watch a University Challenge and go, 'I wanna be like them - I'm going to start reading books'. I've accepted I'm never going to be like them. I can't play along.
All I tend to do is-is-is I-I say to Suzanne, right to every question now I'm going to have egg as the answer.
Ricky bursts out laughing
- And I'm hoping that one day
(Laughing) What an amazing game!
Ricky and Steve laugh
What an amazing intellectual pursuit that is!
What a lucky lady!
(laughs) What does Suzanne say to that?
Well, she just sees if it it works. She just plays along, and then I'm saying "Oh, it might be this one" or whatever.

I love that, because I remember once -it was about five years ago- Karl and Suzanne were around near Christmas, and me and Jane were there. We're playing different parlor games, like charades and that. And then one game-- You have to do that thing, where, you have to beat- And you have to do animals and you have to go: First one is A, then B. So you say: aardvark. Next one goes: beaver. Next one goes: cat. It came to Karl, he panicked, and he went: egg.
Steve laughs
And he was on egg!

So you're sat there, watching University Challenge and on a good night, it's, you know: "Well-known jeweler of Faberg's-- well known for his jeweling encrusted what?" "Egg." "Humpty Dumpty is commonly pictured as a living...?" "Egg."
(laughing) That's great!
That's what I'm saying. If you keep saying the same thing, eventually-- It's like a broken watch.
"Karl Pilkington's head looks like a...?"
I've just got more chance of getting it right.
Sure.
But also, he told me when he plays University Challenge, he said he's given up ever trying to get an answer. So now, he tries to guess who's going to answer the question.
Steve & Ricky laugh
Another great game! Unbelievable! How do you do with that?
I'm normally alright on that.
(laughs) "I'm normally alright on that"!
There's got to be something else... to watch.
There's another evolution thing though. When you watch brainy people on that, all are wearing glasses. What does that tell you? We are reading too much. We're wearing the eyes out.
Hmmmm. Maybe.
And you can't argue with that. Because the evidence is there.
Well, you can...

Most people on University Challenge -which is a quiz show, if people don't have that in the country- it's the brainiest quiz of all time, innit? To be honest, I don't know why they don't go on 'Who Wants to Be a Millionaire?' or something. Because they'll get a better prize than-- What do they win on University Challenge?
Because they'll be stitched up by a question of "Who's in Hollyoaks?" It will be--, yeah.
It'll be... "What characters Andy Lincoln played in This Life?" and they won't get it and you'll go: "Egg". And you'll be correct!
But that's... that's the thing, innit? There's snobbery on, like, braininess. The way that-- if you're a specialist in... I don't know what's, something...
Well, no, don't-- Go on, finish-- You've started a conversation, you're halfway through a sentence, you've got a point to make...
Can't get out now!
Okay.
Say, if you're a specialist in...
Go on.
...Latin tattoos.
Ricky & Steve laughs
"Latin tattoos"! I didn't know you wanted something so specific.
So that's a tattoo you have on your arm with "Cogito ergo sum" underneath, or is it a tattoo...
It's just a... Well, it's the only reason Latin's still alive innit?
Right.
Right.
Tattooists. So you go on, Mastermind...
Yeah.
And people will go, 'Ooh, he's clever, in't 'e. He got 40 correct in 60 seconds.'
Yeah.
Now if you go on and say any questions about Coronation Street between 1990 and 92, people go, 'Oh he's a bit of a knob,' because there's a snobbery to education.
Yes, there is.
But a question is still a question, innit?
Well, to a certain degree. Although, yeah, that's fine, um but there's no application to knowing who played Ena Sharples, whereas presumably there is something useful in um-
Well, not perhaps Latin tattoos-
No not Latin Tattoos, no.

Because none of us have established exactly what that is. But if you're knowledge- you have knowledge of, you know, astrophysics, obviously that's going to be, you know, as Ricky says, it's going to take more application to become an expert on that than watching Coronation Street twice a week.
But it's still information that you've had to learn.

You've not learned it, though. You've just sat down in front of the telly and it's just piped into your brain very directly and very easily and enjoyably. Let's say, the people working on that microchip, that one day you'll have in your brain, are they not doing something more interesting and valuable for society than the Coronation Street fella?
No, 'cause Coronation Street- that fella who knows a lot about it, he's- at least he's enjoying his time watching that.
We're not saying he's not enjoying it.
Sorry he's enjoying it. But, ya know, a brain in a jar can be enjoying it if it doesn't know it's a brain in a jar.
All right. So what're you asking me?
But we were talking-
Steve laughs
Didn't seem a difficult point, what we were saying. We were saying-
What I mean is-
Okay, one more go. What do you mean?
The chip in the brain. Isn't part of filling your head with stuff the journey of filling it with that stuff?
Ricky and Steve laugh
What do you mean?

Whereas if I just- If I'm, say if you had a baby, the baby pops out, it cries a bit. They go, 'Right, what do you want your baby to be interested in?' And you say, 'I want it to be a plumber.' You go, 'Right. When it's two, we're going to stick a plumber chip in its head.'
Right.
Yeah.
It's not right, is it?
No. No. I don't know why he chose plumber either.
Well, we still need plumbing doing.
Yeah, I know we do. But-
It's odd that they would have chosen, but they've got such, such kind of small ambitions for their baby.
It's what his granddad did, and they want the sort of the thing to go through the business. They own a plumbing business. They want the baby to carry on the business.
They want the baby to be able to plumb.

It goes on now, where parents force the kids into riding horses and you see the kid without the parents about and you go, 'do you like horses?' And they go, 'No, not really. Being forced to get on a horse. Can't stand 'em.' And people would go, 'that's wrong. The kids should have the freedom to decide if it wants to get on an horse or not.'
That's right, yeah.
Well, what about this chip in the head?
But you've made this up.
But you've made this scenario up.
They're not putting chips in baby's heads.
I thought you said they were.
No.
When did I say that? I never said that.

I think Steve's point- and I don't know, I haven't read it, but I imagine he's saying it's the next step in convenience with technology, an interface between a human and a research tool, or fun. You know, computers went from being the size of a room to a thing you can wear on your watch. So the next step may be you won't forget your palm top, you won't forget your ipod, you won't forget your laptop. It's in there.
I know, but it's makes us lazy.

But you-- You straightaway thought that now it went to some sort of weird laboratory, where it's all white, and there's just a doctor... And everyone's in a silver suit, right? And they go "We're removing your... the self. We're removing the self and putting in chip! You are now Computer Boy!" "I want to watch Coronation Street!" "Well, you won't in a few seconds." (whooses) "I hate Coronation Street, me."
Karl it's not a question-- It's not that Google is now Karl.
Ricky laughs
It looks like Karl, but it's just spamming, you know, little pop-ups about offers you can buy, and all the cheap holidays here and there.
"He's not the man I married!"
Right. Look at it like this.
Jesus...
Look, I see it all the time now.
Go on.
You go "Where are you going?" to someone. And you go "I'm going to... Dorset."
Right.
"Alright, what road are you taking?" "Don't know, I'll just pop on the satnav." Now, that's a start, innit?
Okay. Let's act that out with me. Okay? "I'm going away for the weekend, Karl."
"Are you?"
"Yeah."
"Where are you going?"
"Dorset."
"Oh, yeah? How are you getting there?"
"Car."
"Alright, yeah. Which way are you going?"
"Don't know. Why do you want to know?"
"Just making a-- making a friendly chat... Just... You know, I'm interested in geography. Which way are you going?"
"Well, I don't know really. I've got a satnav in my car and I'm getting there--"
"Oooh"
"What do you mean 'Oooh'?"
"Bit lazy, innit?"
"Well, I'm not a pigeon... I don't..."
"Have you got an A-Z?"
"Well, yeah-- I have a computer with the A-Z. What's different between looking at an A-Z and you know
"Lazy though, innit?"
"Not really, no. Why? Why is it any different that I've got it computer...ized, so I can go along? A-Z is a bit dangerous, isn't it? Don't to go to A-Z while you're driving along..."
"Clive, who are you talking to? Because we need to hit the road, we need to get going..."
Well, this fucking idiot who wants to know what road I'm taking... Which is a fucking boring thing to ask anyway..."
"I'm sorry... Who is this twat? Because we really got to get going..."
"Fuck me. He's a fucking dickhead who-- I think he's an A-Z salesman by the looks..."
"Just tell him, we're using the satnav, 'cause it's the quickest, most efficient way of doing it."
"...It's the quickest most efficient way of doing it."
"No, but look-- Look what's happened!"
"Who the fuck are you?!"
"What?!"
Would Columbus found America? If he had a satnav?
Yes! He'd have put in "America" and it would have taken him to America.
No, he wouldn't! He only found it because he got lost! Now, if everybody just...
Hold on! Hold on! How would be-- An undiscovered country, be on a satnav?
No.
Go on.
I just mean...
What's the difference between the satnav and the map, in that regard?
Because I've found some lovely little cafes on roads I've never been on.
Steve & Ricky laugh
I love that it's gone from finding a continent to a little cafe!
I love that! I love that. "I am off to discover the Unknown World!" "Where are you going?" "I don't know yet, it's the unknown world." "What are you taking?" "Just boat--" "Oh! Lazy! Swim you cunt!"
I love the fact that he's so luddite now, he's annoyed at the satnav! I mean you'd have probably given Columbus a hard time, "Oh, got a compass! Don't you know where north is?!"
Noughties you twat!
I just think there's something in being lost. I never feel lost, I just think "Oh, I've had a diversion." Because you find-- You find new things
Suzannes is asking the French peasant where the...
I just think, you know, Columbus...
Alright, what's an interesting thing you found when lost?
Like I say, they normally-- I found a shop that was like a fancy dress shop.
Amazing.
Do you need a fancy dress?
Dressed up as Columbus, went and bought a satnav, went to Dorset for the weekend.
Why do you need a fancy dress shop? That sounds like-- If there's one thing you would hate, it's a fancy dress.
Yeah but I like looking at the... They had,like, a space helmet in there.
Right? So you found a fancy dress shop. Where were you supposed to be going that you had time to get sidetracked and go in a...
I think I was going to a meeting.
Steve laughs
Amazing! That's the last time--
You were not supposed to get lost! You were going to a meeting!
Yeah, you don't want to get lost before a meeting.
No, because I always give myself loads of time, because I get lost. A lot.
Get a satnav!
No. I'm just saying... That's how you find little treats along the way, and you next time you pass it-- Or next time someone says "Do you know where the fancy dress shop is?" You go "Yeah, I do..."
"I've got no idea, because I was lost, I don't remember where it was."
No, no, no.
"Oh, I'm not going to tell you! Lazy cunt, have you got an A-Z?" "Oh that's harsh!"
"Yeah, find it yourself you lazy twat!"
"What if I get lost?" "Good. You might find another one!"

It just goes back to the chip thing in the head. I think, you've got to learn along the way. We can't get lazy. We can't have chips in the head, knowing how to plumb. That's what it's all about, innit? And making mistakes. If you make a mistake-- I've done some wiring, got a little shock. Won't happen again.
It will. I've seen that experiment with you before.
What have you learned? You keep going on about all this learning, what have you learned?

Yeah. What have you learned? Okay, sum up-- Sum up mankind's foray into the future. I want this-- This will be the introduction to a book about the future. It will then be read in 100 years time, and go: "Karl Pilkington was the most prophetic genius that's ever walked the Earth. These are his words from 2010..."
Just some predictions.
Just sum it up. I believe-- Start off with "I, Karl Pilkington believe that mankind in the future will..." Okay? Start off with that sentence.
And then what, just have like, a top five?
Well no, just-- Just--
Just predictions. Just predictions of the future.
Okay yeah. And then a little thing to remember, "And remember you this!" So: "I, Karl Pilkington, predict that in the future mankind will..."
Start off with that. Start off with that sentence. I've given you that one.
Alright, I'm Karl... And... The future...
He's already gone off road!
It's a scary place. But... the future is going to happen. There's no getting away from that.
Yeah. And your predictions are...
We're all... (humms)
It's not a sound bite...
Hang on! Give him space, give him space!
Hang on, this is the beggining of my book!
I've got to think about... I don't want to get it wrong.
Think, okay-- Think first, think and then say-- Okay. Starting from now. These words of wisdom will be... inscribed... on the wall of a museum one day. Proceed!
Or a wall of a lavatory...
I think trousers... are going to be stopped being made.
Silent laugh from Ricky
Just because you see kids now, they've got their pants around their ankles. They're going further and further down. So I think-- That's evolution. Just getting rid of the trouser...
Right
...It's just dropping naturally.
Ricky still laughs in the background
That's the evolution of the trouser... Because it's dropping... Increasingly down the arse?
You see now some kid's underpants. So they're just dropping. I think they'll get to a point when they just don't bother wearing them anymore.
Right.
Prediction one! That's an amazing one!
They'll stop making treasures in the future. Okay.

We're going to get weaker. That's already happened. We used to say, you know, "An apple a day, keeps the doctor away." Now they're saying, eat five fruits. So we've definitely-- That's-- That's evidence. You can't argue with that! I probably put that first, because they go "Right, what's number two?" So swap that round.
Okay. That's number one.
Give them the pants second.
Yep.
Ricky chuckling
(laughing) I'm gonna die! I'm gonna die! "They used to say 'an apple a day, keeps the doctor away'. They used to say...!"
"They used to say, 'pull your trousers up', now they say 'pull them down, you cunt!'"
(laughing) I've never heard such fucking drivel in my life!
Number three!
Right. Number three. The scholars are now waiting with baited breath when they find this old scroll. And they go "Oooh, what can number three be?"
I reckon... we'll blend all our food.
Steve & Ricky burst laughing
Oh god! I honestly thought then, that he's going to make a point about race... And then he comes out with "We'll blend all our food!" (slaps his knees)
Like they do for babies, you mean?
Yeah. I just think-- When you think about all the stuff we eat now-- Cavemen, chewing on big lumps of meat.
Yeah
Yeah
We had wisdom teeth. Now they're saying take them out, you're not using them. Why are you not using them? Because your food is soft. Sorbet. Soups. Everything's softer...
Just those two, but yeah
When you get an avocado, they say, "is it soft?" Everyone's squeezing the food before they buy it. No one wants anything tough.
Yeah.
So I think chewing is a... sort of thing of the past. We haven't got the time to chew. Everyone's like "Hurry up! Eat that! You only have to go out for dinner with Ricky: He's like "Hurry up!"
Well, he does blend his food, I think.
Okay, so blending food...
Right.
I reckon... What else do we do now? I've done teeth, done trousers... I've come up with this idea...
Ricky giggles
It's sort of like glasses, but you can live wherever you want to live.
What do you mean?
Everything that's real... You're not looking at that anymore. This is really the future. I put this at number ten. This is like...
We're only doing five, fuck me!
Alright then.
What you mean is that you look through the glasses and instead of seeing what-- The real world, you see a tropical paradise...
What you want to see. So if you're a young kid and you like the idea of living in the urban ghetto, with all graffiti on the walls and that, you can see that.
Yeah, but hold on. Are you walking around, because you'll be bumping into stuff, aren't you?
No.
Why not?
No, what you mean is that the stuff that's there in the real world is being digitally reimagined in your glasses, so...
Yeah
...What was a nice country lane is suddenly now an urban ghetto?
It's got loads of graffiti on it.
Sure.
Absolutely mental, pointless, would never work...
But...
Absolutely one of the maddest things you've ever said!
It's so... really weird, that one.
It could be done. I reckon it could be... easily done.
Why would it be?
Okay, last one. That's number four -a load of bollocks- So what's number five?
There'll be-- there'll be more letters in the alphabet.
Ricky & Steve laugh
Why?
Why?
Because... we're running out of words now, aren't we?
No, we're not running out of words.
We are. We are definitely running out.
No.
Just using the letters we've already got, we're making new words.
Yeah.
No, but we haven't got enough now.
Of course we have! Have you any idea-- You could have a word with nine 'L's before you run out.
Yeah. And they do in Wales and what have you-- That because their alphabet is shorter than ours. They've only got something like 24 letters over there.
Right.
They go mental with the 'L'. Now what we do is, we've got 26 letters, but we are now struggling.
We're not struggling at all.
We are.
We're not. It's just a stupid...
Boswollocks! In shampoo. Now there's a word where they've gone "We've invented something here! We've got something, we're putting in shampoo"
Boswollocks?
Boswollocks.
You just made up?
No. (laughs) They go: "New, with Boswelox and cermide-R." Yeah, but that's a new word because they have to invent--
But it's a terrible word.
Why?
Boswollocks!
(laughs) Yeah but it's another word.
Is that real? You made that up?
Yeah. Boswollocks, yeah.
This is what I'm saying. So years ago when they came up with all the sensible ingredients...
Go on.
...Sodium.
Ricky laughs
"Sodium!" He likes sodium, doesn't like boswollocks!
That sounds all right.
Because that sounds like something... like an ingredient.
Well yeah, but that's because you're used to it.
Is this a load of Boswollocks? Are you winding me up? The two of you
No. It's real.

It's real. And that's because, 26 letters we've wasted them-- Years ago we went mental with the, you know, "pneumonia", sticking a 'P' on it... And there's loads of words where you go "What's that letter doing in there?" Whereas now, you can't do that. They've gone "Whoa, pull that back, why is that letter there"
Who has?!
Now you've got stuff like abbreviations and stuff.
Yeah

Let's not waste letters. Let's just control it a little bit. Things-- Cars are called things like, you know, 'GTI' or something because they're going "Well, I can't think of a word to call this" So they're giving them letters.
Think of a word now! Think of a word that hasn't been made up!
What do you mean?
Tell me a word that hasn't been made up.
Made up.
All words have been made up.
No. One that hasn't. That could be used-- Say if I invent something now to put in shampoo, what can I call it? Quick!
"Cranbruley."
No, it's too close to... No, we can't get that past the advertising person.
"Scrimpton"
..."Scrimpton"?
Yeah.
Ricky & Steve laugh
It took Ricky two goes, and you accepted his second one!
Well, I think we've sorted out the future.
Wow.
Jingle

Since obviously the days of Nostradamus, there's been many people who've tried to foresee the future. Karl, I'm not sure if you're familiar, but there's endless, you know, predictions. Apparently there are other planets that may collide with ours, you know, there's some scientific basis on this. And obviously, I don't know if you've been seen the posters for that recent film '2012', well, that's based on this notion of some kind of Mayan calendar which supposedly predicts the end of the world as being 2012. But if you knew with certainty that today was the end of the world, how would you spend that final day? I mean, -this seems weird to me- but I think I would-- I'd like to experience a lot of the extremes of existence. So, for instance, I've always wanted to smash up a bar. Do you know what I mean? It seems strange, but I've always wanted the exhilaration of just smashing all those bottles, like you see in a film.
But would you enjoy it as much, knowing that you're going to die in 8 hours?
I don't know. I suppose it's the sense of abandon. You know? I mean, maybe I'd murder a person.
Wow.
I don't know. But I think I'd probably go mental. I've always been a very reserved person, you know? I've never gotten in a fight, never caused a rumpus...

Yeah, but that's a worrying thought, because we have to have the end of the world for it to be the end of your world. Because a lot of people know that they're terminally ill so... They don't go around smashing up bars and killing people.
But I suppose I'll know there'll be no repercussions ultimately, because...
They're gonna die anyway.
...The next day everyone's gone. There's not going to be mourning families.
But then how dare you deprive that person of his last 8 hours or 10 hours of life?
I don't care, because it's the last day on earth.
Well, that's true...
I know the moral guilt that I'll feel is over in a few hours.
Morality isn't relative just to repercussion, is it? Because...
No, but the point is to--

You can do things without repercussion. Often people say, you know, "What would you do if you never got caught?" Or would you do it if there is repercussions for that person, as grave as they might be, just because you feel that it's no big deal either way, that they're only going to live another 8 hours, they might feel differently. And you're saying, well, you won't care because you won't be around. But then why do people care about their loved ones when they won't be around? Why do people get a will ready?
Because my point is that they know that those people will continue to live for an indeterminate amount of time.
So you do care about the other person's feelings then?
Of course I do. But my point is, knowing that everyone is going to be wiped off the face of the earth the following day, all those repercussions are no longer quite the same.
I'd find it hard to divorce myself from my morality that's ingrained, just because it doesn't matter anymore.

Yeah. But I mean... Honestly, to me it seems that we're approaching... just the end of all things. And so, I'm saying that there's something about the fact that we're all going to end that somehow seems very liberating.
What would you do?
I've always wanted to kick a duck up the arse.
Steve & Ricky burst laughing
Jingle

Now obviously, the future is relative. Us talking now, the future is one thing, the past is another. But to someone in the past, we are in the future. So, Karl: If you could go back into any era, okay? You are what you are now, you are you as you sit there now, your age, with all your memories and all your input and all your advantages on ages gone by. And all your advantages over people gone by... Where would you go? What would you do? Don't worry about ramifications, like if you squash a butterfly, you come back here and we're all speaking a different language...
Yeah, but I don't believe all that.
Of course you should!
They should have picked something better than a butterfly. The thing about if you kill a butterfly, there's a volcano somewhere...
Right?
There (makes a noise)
Okay, what did that noise mean?
It's just passing the buck, innit? It's kind of like blaming a butterfly... They only live about a day! So you blame it and it's dead anyway, and there's no evidence left. It's a stupid argument.
Is that the theory? Is that the theory, that you're blaming a butterfly for a volcano... I'm not sure that's it, is it?
Ricky sighs
Yeah, it wafts its wings...

When it wafts, right... When a butterfly wafts, if you stop the waffery, then the whole world has changed, because there was no waft on a certain day. Okay? But that means that everything's part of the causal web-- It's a model for determinism. So things do-- Yeah, of course things have an effect on everything else.
Yeah, but I'm just saying that's a bad example. The butterfly doing its wings.
Well, no. That butterfly might have flown into a car window and frightened someone and they crashed.
Use a wasp!
Ricky laughs
Why? Why is that preferable?
Because you do panic! I've been in a car and there's a wasp knocking about, it's terrifying! Yeah, I can see how that could cause a disaster. A butterfly, you just go "Oh, open the other window."
Ricky cackles
I love the fact that you won him over to that theory now, just by substituting a butterfly and a wasp...

You think back to perhaps when you were teenager, or even before, when you were growing up, you had visions, I suppose, of your own personal future and how that would play out, how you could change the way you lived your life in order to affect the future. I'm very lucky in some regards that one of my ambitions was always to be involved with comedy-
Yeah. It's funny though, isn't it?
And I was clear sighted about that, and I was lucky that I've managed to achieve that. A lot people don't even know what they want from their future.

Well, the other thing is that when you dream of where you'll be in 20 years time, you don't change the future, you don't change the buildings and you just think of yourself sort of richer, having a happier life, you know what I mean?
Yeah. And also
I was always slightly more handsome in the future.
Ricky laughs

Like I kept imagine I would grow a little more handsome. People get so-- My grandmother kept telling me "You'll fill out! When you fill out a bit..." She was obsessed with me filling out. This is why she would feed me endlessly, the idea that somehow if I was less gangly...
Yeah. It worked with me though.
Yeah, you just... really filled out.

I filled out, yeah. It's funny because I still forget what I look like now, in the present. In my head, I still look like I used to look. Then I catch a little glimpse of myself in the shop window and go "Who's that fat-- Oh! Oh, no..." Do you know what I mean? I'm so much better..

But you've journeyed a long way. I mean, you were a good looking lad, and you are... I mean, it's preposterous. I mean, everyone I work with, or meet who's seen a picture of you as a teenager, doesn't understand it. I mean, I pretty much look the same. I haven't changed much. I'm still a constant disappointment to myself in a way, you know? When I put on a tuxedo, that's the best I'm ever going to look, and I don't look like James Bond... Whereas you at least had a moment where you looked alright-- Honestly, it's Jane I feel sorry for! Because, she did not sign up for this!
Ricky laughs
Well, we've all changed...
No, I've seen pictures of the past- She ain't changed much. Whereas you...
No, I don't mean that. We've all changed. We all changed. Karl used to have hair.
Yeah, but by your own admission didn't have it for long. You didn't have it for long, did you?

No, it wasn't-- Didn't want to hang around, my hair. It was never-- Told you, that it didn't feel needed, so it went. I never did anything with it. It was hair of a Chinaman, right? Even the hairdresser said. He said "You can do nothing with this." I said "what do you mean?" He said it's just too... limsy.
"Limsy"!
"Limsy"?
Sorry, was that...?
Limp or flimsy, I reckon?
Well, no, Lim See is a Chinaman. Gave his name... to the limp hair... of the... Chinese race.
So you think your hair bailed on you because it was not getting treated well enough?

I think that's true. I think that's how it works. But, yeah, I know what you mean. I sort of think about if I've changed and that, but I don't think I have that much. Still have the same sort of thoughts... I like olives now.
Steve laughs slightly
Which I didn't like probably three years ago.
Right. Hmmm, interesting.
But if you eat four in a row, you get a taste for them and I thought "Go on, I'll have five." I thought, "Yeah, they're alright, these." So that's different. But other than that...
So what were your dreams and ambitions when you were young?
Didn't have any. It was kind of...
Right. Five years old: What do you want to be? What are the thoughts of the future?
I didn't worry-- At five years old, you're not worrying about work and that.
Okay. Ten. What's your "Hopes and fears of all the years, Are met in thee tonight."

I wasn't worrying about work till about... it's about 13-14. I was thinking, right, people who I knew had left school, they weren't getting work. I was thinking "Oh, I don't want to be like that." That's when I did boxing. You know, I could have gone down that route. Got into boxing, didn't I?
How many fights you had?
I don't know, about three or four.
How? Only just when does brain can't damage kick in?
I guess it can basically have an almost instant. It must that must be must be part of it.
Were you really - did you really get a bad beating on one of those fights?
Yeah. Leroy gave a really good clackerin'
Clackering. The thing is, your jab was a bit limsey, but Leroy's was clackering.
Then there was the dancing.
I don't remember this - What, break dancing?
Well, I did that. I did a bit of body popping.
Yeah. Did you ever really think that you might do this in the future?
You never know, do ya'
But at the time, do you ever think, oh, I wouldn't mind doing this?

I must have thought that for me to go, well, let's try and join - you know - Twiggy's Dance Club and all that. Me mam and dad always sort of - you know - if you want to give it a go, give it a go. With the boxing, you know, me dad was saying, I'll get you the proper shoes and that. I mean, mam was like, don't don't bother getting in them yet. Let's see if he sticks at it for like, four months, because they were about thirty quid.
Let him carry on in my furry slippers.
Then with the dance and it was the same thing. I said, oh, I need some leg warmers and that.
These tights are just as good. Come on in. Pop on your nan's tights.
Me dad gave me his - he cut the sleeves of a shirt.
Amazing.
And they were your leg warmers.
Yeah...
Amazing.
But it's funny when you're a kid, it doesn't bother you,
But surely cut them off a jumper.
No. I don't know why. I know it looked daft, it had cuffs on leg warmers.
That's amazing. That's amazing!
But when you're a kid, it must.
What did they think down twiggy's?
Have looked Laurence Lewelin-Bowen doing a handstand.
But then that didn't last long. And then me dad - you know - I was getting older now. And he's like...
Dad needed his shirt back for a wedding.
As long as he didn't take his jacket off, it was fine.
"Dad! I'm losing me hair, I need a hat. I don't need a bloody hat. Pop me pants on't head."
But then you've got to make sure you try and get a job. And school was sort of safe.
So 15 now.
Hang on, why did Twiggy's... Why did you stop going to twiggy's?
Well, it was shut wasn't it.
Amazing.
Oh, it closed down?

Closed down. It had a load of toilet rolls in there. It been turned into like a storage unit. I've never really had like a dream. I've just bumbled along because, like I've said, it's that thing of sort of.
Bumbled. Clackered. Bumbled. Limsey. It's like call my fucking bluff.

There's no point sort of wishing for too much because if you don't get it, you'll be fed up. So it's better just to sort of go, well, let's see what's around the corner. This is what I've said to you about a sat-nav system, right? It's the same thing. Yeah, sure. After sat-nav, type in where you want to go and they'll take you straight there. What I say is use the back streets. Have a look around. Turn off. Don't go straight ahead. Turn right. The little dead ends have a look.
You might get mugged.
Have a look.
Don't go down the dead ends.
Why not?
You got a reverse.
Have a look.
Well, there's nothing there. It's dead end.
What's the road doing there then?
What's the dead end?
But there must be something down there.
There's nothing. It just ends.
Just a wall.
Right? So it's not a problem. Reverse. [hums]
Don't go down in the first place if you know it's a dead end. Don't tell people dead end, then they've got to reverse out. Difficult.
Well, I'd say just have a look. You see, that's the difference between me and you. I have a look down the dead end.
It's a dead end. No, don't worry--
What's down there?
There's nothing, mate. Dead end.
Rubbish? Just a load of rubbish?
Yeah, no nothing. Dead end.
Nothing at all?
Yeah, no point in going down there. Dead end.
Right? So I'll go, well, I'll just have a look for myself because I don't believe you.
Okay, well, go on then.
Right, I'll have a look. Ooh, look at this I've found!
What have you found?
Just... box of money that you didn't know about.
Ricky and Steve laugh
All I'm saying is it could be anything.
He has still got the brain of a ten year old, hasn't he?
A box of money!
He's still got the brain of a ten year old.
Steve sighs.
I'm just- I- set your stall out--
Right. So where's the stall? Where are you setting up stall? Not in a dead end.
Yeah, 'cause there's not through-traffic--
There's no thoroughfare. Yeah, you want- you want to be on a sort of public highway.
This is crazy.
Where are you setting your stall out? [Sniggers] What are you selling? What are you selling?
Well, this is what I'm saying to you.
What are you selling, first?
I'm selling a mixture of stuff.
What, like what?
All sorts.
What have you bought it with? A bag of money you found in the dead end?
Leg warmers.
You got- you got- new leg warmers with, um, c-- "D'ya want-- have you got-- you want cufflinks with them?"
Steve laughs.
"What?" "D'ya want cufflink with them leg warmers?" "Well no, why would I do that?" "Well you've gotta fucking look smart, in't ya, ya cunt?"
Ricky and Steve laugh.
So you're selling, uh, what are you selling?
Look-
Yeah.
You set your stall out.
Yeah.
Right.
Yeah.
Now, isn't it dangerous to sell all the same product in that shop?
Right.
Okay, where's this--
I don't know what you're talking about now.
Where's the analogy going?
Yeah.
This is a metaphor. I think this is a metaphor.
Yeah.
Erm...
What are you selling? What you're selling, first? Bang! 2,3,4. Quick, it's The Apprentice. It is.
No, but this is what I'm saying to you, though.
Go on. Right.
I just said to you--
Yeah.
You--
Yeah.
Well, I don't know what you wanted to do. You haven't told me, but--
Right.
I'm saying--

D'you want me to tell you what I wanted to be when I-- wanted to be? Right, at 5 years old I wanted to own a sweet shop until my mum said "You know you've got to buy the sweets first." Right? From 10, I wanted to be like a scientist. 15, a vet kicked in. Alright?
But at some point, you jettisoned all of that to try and pursue a pop career.
20: I wanted to be a pop star. 25: I thought I'd better get a job.
Well...
At 30 I did.
Me saying turn off the main road and do a right--
Yes.
-is saying, just have a look around. In the same way that if you go into a shop--
It was s metaphor, wasn't it?
Yeah.
Right.
It was, yeah.
Yeah.
In the same way that you go into a shop--
Mm.
-you're thinking, "I'm getting a quarter of bom boms"--
Right. Bom boms. Bom. Boms.
But by the time you get to the counter--
You're clackered!
-and you get some liquorice all sorts instead, because you thought, "Actually, I forgot about them."
Sorry, now this isn't a metaphor, is it? This is- this is a real shop now, isn't it?
I just, uh, I just mean you're going to be let down. You're going to be very, very disappointed with life if, uh... y'know--
If what? If what? If what?
If the thing you're aiming for--
Yeah.
-doesn't happen.

But what if it does happen? I'd like to take issue with this because there's a lot of young people who listen to our podcasts and if they listen to y-- this tripe, that if you try for something in life it won't happen, so don't bother. I think it's a bloody disgrace. Imagine if Leona Lewis had thought that when she went on the bloody X Factor. She wouldn't have got punched by that bloke in that--
Ricky laughs.
Well alright, that doesn't make sense. But you know what I mean. She would not be living her dreams.
Yeah, but we don't know what Leona wanted to do, she might have a backup plan.
...That's why she's done it!
She might have had a backup plan!
Yeah but she fulfilled the main ambition, which was to sing! That's why she went on the show! She didn't go there because she thought "Oh, I might want to work down a branch of Waterstones"
You think she went in there and said "Quarter of bom-boms" (mumbles) "This is X-Factor." And she went "Oh, go on then."
Ricky sniffs
"Well, have a sing!"
Well, what about the girl who looked like a fat baby? She went on there with a dream. It's not going to happen!
Ricky laughs
Yeah

But the point is, I'm not saying you all have to go on The X-Factor, if you're a hopeless idiot, I'm saying if you've got a little bit of talent and you pursue it, it might take you somewhere. If you want to be a vet or a doctor or pop star, you might have a chance. You might as well have a stab for it, instead said, "Alright, I'll just sit around in me underpants."
Yeah, they're doing a new one, "The X-Ray Factor", where you can actually become, you know, a top radiologist.
Steve laughs
But I've said this for for an idea.
Go on.

I think they should do that. Because how many singers do we need in the world? You see, that's the thing, we're talking about the future. I think-- We're not going to talk anymore. I think... it's going to be like living in an opera. The way things are going on now, everyone wants to sing. Whereas, if you did a TV program to try and get a doctor, you know...
"X-Ray Factor"
You know, it's all about, you know, getting in young kids, do live surgery, you know, there's big cues anyway. People are queuing up to have operations done.
Yeah.
So you say "Look, Hilda. You have got a problem with your with your left foot bunion. You can either wait for your proper doctor and hospital -but it's going to be a two year waiting list-
Or you can have Jedward do it for you.
Ricky giggles
"-Or, you're free Saturday night. Live."
Because we've got two 17 year olds, who are going to do it.
"Hilda!"
She comes out.
Ricky cackles
He did a little voice!
I've never even do a little voice before! Do it again? Okay, good. So this is-- Okay, what is this? This is a talent show, where people can have a go at being...
A doctor.
This is like something from the Middle Ages.
But they need volunteers, who would rather have... an apprentice, someone have a go...
It's not even an apprentice. It's someone with no training at all.
Yeah.
They learn how to do major operations in a week.
But no, not major ones. That's for the final.
Yeah, of course you've got to train up to that, sure.
A heart transplant. You build them up.
A heart transplant for the final! That's amazing.
So anyway, it's Hilda. And Hilda's not the person-- She's not operating, she's just the person who needs a bunion removed.
She's got the foot problem, yeah.
Right.
So she comes in, they have a quick chat with her.
Have a chat with her, "How's your life been?", -bit of Coldplay under her- She's going "Oh, it's terrible, I can hardly walk and all that." And they go "Right."
"Here's a fowl who looks like a baby." And you think this is a good-- You don't see any problems with this so far? You've not identified any... concerns yet.
If it means you get younger people into other jobs, other than singing
I agree with you. I think it's crazy that everyone now, just wants to be famous- A singer or something. and we don't need them. They're just contriving it-
I'm sick of-
All they're doing is knocking the last one off the number one- So it's just a factory.

But I'm not talking about everyone should try and be a singer, am I? What I'm saying is, sometimes you're allowed to pursue your dreams and you may fulfill those dreams. There's nothing wrong with that!
But Steve, Steve, Steve
It may be, that you want to operate on a woman called Hilda with a bunion. Pursue that dream! But according to your negative views, we shouldn't even try and do that either.
Steve, what
Go on. What's he saying?
Leona was an example! I'm not saying everyone should try and be like Leona!
No. Listen to his point, Steven, because he's got a very good point coming up. Now!
Here it comes. This is it.
Okay? He hasn't said a... normal word yet! But he's going to say some now, and they're all going to be profound.
People's dreams... Aren't their own dreams.
Oh, hold on! What do you mean by that?
Okay. Keep going, keep going! Let- No, no, no! He'll explain! Don't you-- don't need to ask any questions, he'll explain.

Because they think they know what they want, because they see it on the telly. They see, you know, someone singing a song and they go "I want to do that." So all I'm saying is: Change the dreams. Change the dreams.
Yeah.
To what?
Surgery.
Ricky sniggers

They're watching that, they're seeing Hilda, happy. With a better foot. The doctors getting all the praise, they go "I want a bit of that action!" That's what it's about. They don't want to be singers! They want to be known, they want to be famous. So, fine, have a bit of fame, but do some good! Fix Hilda's foot!
Sorry, was that the end of the point?
Yeah, because all we've done, we've changed our dreams. Dreams--

Well, you leave it on a good point there, because what is astounding is that when, you know... People are inundated with praise for people who are just clothes horses, they are just skinny nobodies, who don't do anything except to have their picture taken and they're role models... -I'm not talking about anyone in particular- But it's just these people, who want to be seen with other celebrities, and marry celebrities, and be a celebrity. People think that's an easy life because they're getting rewarded for it. And yet, someone who's stuck in the laboratory trying to come up with a cure for AIDS, they don't know or care about them. And...

Okay. Can I just point out, though that if we're going to have a go at people being successful, making money, and being well known for doing nothing of any value... I point you to the man sat opposite me here...
Ricky giggles
That's... Hey, I tell you, there's times when I lie awake at night thinking what was me dreams?
"I've got a new boiler. And 2 houses."
Yeah. Hold on! I'd love to be a little doctor.
Yeah, I mean, it's past me now, there's no way I can go back.
Well...
But it would have been brilliant
You're wrong!
(show host voice) "Karl Pilkington!"
"Hilda?!"

"What is it now? Hilda, what's up with you?" "I've got terrible piles... There's some sort of blockage up there. I haven't gone to the... Excuse me... Haven't gone to the toilet for a week." "Well... Karl, can you unblock Hilda's arse?" "Now live, unblocking Hilda's arse: Karl Pilkington!"
I thought she had bad feet!

No, the feet-- Jedward fixed her feet. There's a lovely job, that's why they stayed in last week. Her arse is worse than her feet. It's because she's been off her feet for so long, because she couldn't walk, her arse took the brunt of it. And it's just terrible. Piles of burst-- It's blocked up there... Well, she just eats her cheese, because she's so depressed.
I'd probably knock it on the head there--
Why?
Because I'd just say, like going back to the street thing. I've gone down the wrong avenue. This isn't for me, I didn't know I'd be eye to eye with this!
Ricky laughs
It's not for me. And that's how you find out that it's not for you, by doing it.
Right.
But at least I gave it a go.
So this is the same as you had one fight with Leroy, you went along to a dance studio with shut, you've seen Hilda's arse, and it's turned you off... proctology.
Once again, you just abandoned it!
Yeah, well that's...
Have a go!
Have a go. Just feel inside Hilda's back passage. Feel the blockage!
No, because the audience have already decided. They've seen a weakness in me, they're going to vote me out. There's no point me getting dirty fingers for this!
Ricky wheezes with laughter
Jingle
Well, that's about it for the Ricky Gervais Guide to The Future, the next audiobook in this series is the Ricky Gervais Guide to the Human Body. Look forward to that.
Will do.
It's goodbye from me, Ricky Gervais, Steven Merchant
Goodbye.
And the little round headed shaven chimp that is, forever, Karl Pilkington.
Alright?
Outro music
Audible hopes you've enjoyed this program.

synopsis.description: Karl answers "Egg" to every question on University Challenge

trivia.description: Hollyoaks is a British soap opera which began airing on Channel 4 on 23 October 1995.
Andrew Lincoln, is an English actor. His first major role was as the character Edgar "Egg" Cook in the BBC drama This Life.
'Boswelox' is a real thing, extracts used from Boswellia plant by L'Oreal in their beauty products.
Waterstones: A mainstream and academic book retailer that encourages browsing; some stores have cafes.
John and Edward Grimes, collectively known as Jedward, are an Irish singing duo. They are identical twins who first appeared as John & Edward in the sixth series of The X Factor in 2009.
